title: What Credit Score Do You Need to Rent a Home?
seoTitle: Credit Score Needed to Rent a Home
summary: Worried your credit score will hold you back from renting? Here's what landlords really look for, what to do if your score is low, and tips to get approved for housing with less-than-perfect credit.

body.raw:
## Landlords look past the number‚Äîhere‚Äôs how to pass screening even if your score isn‚Äôt perfect. Worried your score will sink your rental? The truth: most places don‚Äôt use a single cutoff. Here‚Äôs how credit fits into screening‚Äîand what to do if you‚Äôre not at 700.

Quick links for , :

  • Local rental assistance programs
 ## Start here: what to do first - List your strengths: stable income (typically 2.5‚Äì3√ó rent), on-time bill history, solid references, no evictions, clean criminal court records. You‚Äôll use this to balance a ‚Äújust-OK‚Äù score. - Pull your own credit reports and fix errors before you apply (disputes can remove wrong addresses, duplicate collections, or paid debts). - Build a simple ‚Äúrenter packet‚Äù: ID, last 3 pay stubs, offer letter or benefits award, last 2 bank statements, past landlord contacts, and a 1‚Äì2 paragraph cover note explaining anything unusual. - Have plan B ready: a co-signer/guarantor, larger deposit, or a few months of rent in savings can offset a middling score. - If you‚Äôre credit invisible/thin file, bring proof of positive history (on-time utilities, phone, or rent receipts) and consider rent-reporting to build score over time. ## There‚Äôs usually no hard minimum: how rental risk scoring actually works **Tiny scenario:** Two applicants both show ‚Äú650.‚Äù One has medical collections from years ago but steady income and clean rentals; the other has recent missed payments and high debt. The first may get approved faster. - Property managers may use **rental-specific models** (e.g., a ‚Äúresident score‚Äù) that weigh factors differently than standard credit scores. - Many screens look at **patterns**‚Äîrecent delinquencies, high credit utilization, or unresolved collections matter more than an old paid account. - Income and **debt-to-income** can weigh heavily; some buildings require a specific income multiple regardless of score. - **Evictions/judgments** and open bankruptcies are bigger red flags than a single low number. - Expect variation by **market and building class**: corporate-managed buildings may set higher thresholds than small landlords. - If you‚Äôre denied, you have a right to an **adverse action notice** telling you which report/score was used and how to request it. ## Renting with less-than-perfect credit: practical ways to say ‚Äúyes‚Äù **Tiny scenario:** Your score is 605 after a rough patch. You offer a co-signer, provide two months‚Äô bank statements showing cash cushion, and agree to enroll in autopay; the landlord approves with a slightly higher deposit. - **Strengthen the file:** stable income letters, proof of emergency savings, and clean rental history references. - **Offer risk-reducers:** larger deposit (where legal), a few months‚Äô rent upfront, autopay, or a **co-signer/guarantor** (understand fees and obligations). - **Target the right listings:** smaller owners may review the whole story; large complexes may be stricter but offer ‚Äúconditional approvals.‚Äù - **Time your application:** apply right after a paycheck hits and credit utilization dips (balances lower = often a small score bump). - **Explain the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù:** a brief, factual note about medical bills, divorce, or a one-time lapse‚Äîpaired with proof of current stability‚Äîcan matter. - **Build as you go:** enroll in **rent reporting** so on-time payments help your profile for future moves.

## FAQs ### Is 600 enough to rent? Often, yes‚Äîespecially with strong income, clean rental history, or added safeguards (co-signer, larger deposit). Requirements vary by building and market. ### Why is the score on my rental app different from my bank app? Landlords may use rental-focused models or a different score version/date. Expect variation; decisions also consider your full report and income. ### Can I get approved with no credit history? Sometimes. Bring proof of income and positive payment records (e.g., utilities). A co-signer or rent-reporting can help first-time renters. ---
